news_header: Russia's trade has shifted dramatically post-invasion, with China and India becoming key partners, while EU imports plummet.
news_original_title: Russian economy could no longer survive without China, India and Turkey
news_text: Since Russia's invasion of Ukraine in 2022, its trade dynamics have drastically changed. In 2021, nearly 50% of Russian exports went to European countries, primarily energy products. By the end of 2023, China and India emerged as Russia's main export markets, accounting for 32.7% and 16.8% of exports respectively. European nations now represent only about 15% of Russian exports, a significant decline. The shift is attributed to the EU's reduction in Russian oil and gas imports, which have dropped by 90%. This has led to increased trade between Russia and nations that did not impose sanctions, particularly China and Turkey. China's role has become crucial, providing 53% of Russia's imports in 2023, up from 25.7% in 2021. While Russia is adapting to these changes, experts suggest it is not necessarily better off, as the quality of products has declined. The dependence on China raises concerns about Russia's vulnerability in this new trade landscape.
